simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Introspection Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "GraphQL introspection enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found __schema in response data - introspection queries are allowed"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: GraphQL Introspection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returned an explicit \"__schema\" object with a full types listing (including introspection types such as __Schema, __Type, __Field, __Directive). This indicates that GraphQL introspection is enabled and unauthenticated/unauthorized clients can enumerate schema types and available queries/mutations. Exposed schema information helps attackers discover resources, sensitive field names (e.g., User, Wallet, Transaction, Currency), and craft targeted queries or attempts to exploit other issues. Recommended mitigations: disable introspection in production or restrict it behind proper authentication/authorization, enforce query complexity/depth limits, use persisted queries and rate limiting, and audit exposed fields for sensitive data.", "evidence": "Response body contains a top-level \"__schema\" object with a types list (includes __Schema, __Type, __Field, __Directive, etc.)", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "GraphQL Introspection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Response body contains a top-level \"__schema\" object with a types list (includes __Schema, __Type, __Field, __Directive, etc.)", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returned an explicit \"__schema\" object with a full types listing (including introspection types such as __Schema, __Type, __Field, __Directive). This indicates that GraphQL introspection is enabled and unauthenticated/unauthorized clients can enumerate schema types and available queries/mutations. Exposed schema information helps attackers discover resources, sensitive field names (e.g., User, Wallet, Transaction, Currency), and craft targeted queries or attempts to exploit other issues. Recommended mitigations: disable introspection in production or restrict it behind proper authentication/authorization, enforce query complexity/depth limits, use persisted queries and rate limiting, and audit exposed fields for sensitive data."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Field Suggestions Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found \"did you mean\" in error message - field suggestions are enabled"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "safe", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL response includes an explicit field suggestion: \"Did you mean 'abbreviation'?\" which reveals valid schema field names and helps an attacker enumerate the schema. Additionally, the response contains a server stacktrace in extensions.exception.stacktrace, increasing information disclosure. This behavior (field name suggestions) is a known information leakage vector in GraphQL servers. Impact is primarily reconnaissance (helps craft further queries), so severity is low. Mitigations: disable or sanitize validation suggestions and stacktraces in production (e.g., disable debug mode, format/normalize errors to return a generic message for validation failures), and implement strict error handling so schema details are not returned to clients.", "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"abbrevation\\\" on type \\\"Currency\\\". Did you mean \\\"abbreviation\\\"?\" (extensions.exception.stacktrace present)", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"abbrevation\\\" on type \\\"Currency\\\". Did you mean \\\"abbreviation\\\"?\" (extensions.exception.stacktrace present)", "explanation": "The GraphQL response includes an explicit field suggestion: \"Did you mean 'abbreviation'?\" which reveals valid schema field names and helps an attacker enumerate the schema. Additionally, the response contains a server stacktrace in extensions.exception.stacktrace, increasing information disclosure. This behavior (field name suggestions) is a known information leakage vector in GraphQL servers. Impact is primarily reconnaissance (helps craft further queries), so severity is low. Mitigations: disable or sanitize validation suggestions and stacktraces in production (e.g., disable debug mode, format/normalize errors to return a generic message for validation failures), and implement strict error handling so schema details are not returned to clients."}}]
